verses.text: Then the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: God continues His direct guidance of Moses, signifying His active presence among His people. This anticipates the New Testament promise of divine guidance through both scripture and tradition (see Matt. 28:20).

verses.text: “Tell the children of Israel to turn back and camp before Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, opposite Baal-zephon. You shall camp facing the sea.”
verses.comment: God instructs Israel on the precise location for their camp, setting the stage for a miraculous deliverance. The detail here reflects the importance of obedience to specific divine instructions, very much like the detailed guidance seen in later Church practice.

verses.text: For Pharaoh will say about the children of Israel, ‘They are wandering confused in the land; the wilderness has shut them in.’
verses.comment: Pharaoh's perspective is blinded by pride. This passage is a reminder that God's wisdom often confounds human reasoning. (See 1 Cor. 1:27)

verses.text: I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, so he will pursue them. But I will gain honor through Pharaoh and all his army, and the Egyptians will know that I am the LORD.” And they did so.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is seen in the hardening of Pharaoh's heart—this shows how God's plan prevails over man's will. It prefigures the ultimate triumph of Christ over sin and evil.

verses.text: When the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, Pharaoh and his officials had a change of heart toward the people. They said, “Why have we done this? Why have we let Israel leave our service?”
verses.comment: Pharaoh's regret highlights human attachment to power and control. Israel's liberation points toward spiritual freedom that Christ accomplishes.

verses.text: So he readied his chariot and took his army with him.
verses.comment: Pharaoh prepares for battle, signifying a hardened resolve against Israel. This sets up a confrontation between earthly power and divine authority.

verses.text: He took six hundred elite chariots and all the chariots of Egypt, with officers over all of them.
verses.comment: Egypt’s military might is arrayed—a drastic contrast to the seemingly defenseless Israelites, foreshadowing the theme of God delivering His people contrary to human expectation.

verses.text: The LORD hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, so he chased after the Israelites, who were going out boldly.
verses.comment: Israel leaves Egypt with courage—God’s intervention emboldens believers. Spiritual boldness is a gift received in the life of faith (Heb. 10:19).

verses.text: The Egyptians chased them, all Pharaoh's horses, chariots, horsemen, and his army, and overtook them encamped by the sea by Pi-hahiroth, facing Baal-zephon.
verses.comment: Israel is trapped between the sea and the Egyptians—reminds us how deliverance often comes when hope seems lost, a recurring theme fulfilled in Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: As Pharaoh approached, the Israelites looked up, and there were the Egyptians marching after them. They were extremely afraid and cried out to the LORD.
verses.comment: Fear drives the people to earnest prayer. God often uses crises to draw hearts into deeper dependence upon Him.

verses.text: They said to Moses, “Was it because there were no graves in Egypt that you brought us out to die in the wilderness? What have you done to us by bringing us out of Egypt?”
verses.comment: The people quickly lose faith and blame Moses, forgetting God’s prior miracles. This impatience and doubt recur throughout salvation history, urging us toward faith that endures amidst trials.

verses.text: Did we not say to you in Egypt, ‘Leave us alone, so we may serve the Egyptians’? It would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the wilderness.”
verses.comment: Israel’s longing for the seeming 'safety' of slavery shows how fear often tempts believers to settle for less than true freedom in God.

verses.text: But Moses said to the people, “Do not fear! Stand firm and see the salvation of the LORD, which He will accomplish for you today. For the Egyptians whom you see today, you will never see again.”
verses.comment: Moses exhorts them to trust and stand firm—a motif echoed by Christ urging faithfulness even in the face of death (see John 16:33).

verses.text: The LORD will fight for you; you need only to be still.”
verses.comment: Salvation is an act of God, not human effort. This foreshadows the mystery of grace—God fights for us, as ultimately realized in Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Why are you crying out to Me? Tell the children of Israel to go forward.”
verses.comment: God calls for action rooted in trust, reminding us that faith involves a response—moving forward in obedience even when the way seems impossible.

verses.text: But you, raise your staff, stretch out your hand over the sea and divide it, so the children of Israel may go through the sea on dry ground.
verses.comment: God’s use of Moses’ staff as a visible sign points towards how physical means are used to channel divine power. This foreshadows the sacramental principle—God working through material signs.

verses.text: I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they will go in after them, and I will gain glory through Pharaoh and all his army, through his chariots and horsemen.
verses.comment: God’s action reveals Himself as the true sovereign—greater than any earthly ruler. His glory is displayed as He saves His people while judging evil.

verses.text: The Egyptians will know that I am the LORD when I gain glory through Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen.”
verses.comment: Disclosure of the LORD’s identity comes through His mighty acts, carrying the theme of Revelation later fulfilled in Christ’s own works.

verses.text: Then the angel of God, who had been going before the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them. The pillar of cloud also moved from in front and stood behind them.
verses.comment: God’s visible presence protects Israel—this pillar is a figure of God’s continual guidance of His people, paralleling the enduring presence Christ promises His Church.

verses.text: It came between the camp of Egypt and the camp of Israel. There was the cloud and darkness to the Egyptians, but it gave light by night to the Israelites; so neither group approached the other all night.
verses.comment: God separates His people, protecting them in darkness. This foreshadows the spiritual light Christ brings, separating us from the 'darkness' of the world (John 8:12).

verses.text: Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the LORD drove the sea back by a strong east wind all night, and made the sea into dry land; so the waters were divided.
verses.comment: This miracle reveals God's mastery over creation, mirroring Christ's miracles—especially calming the storm. It also points to Baptism: passing through water to new life.

verses.text: The children of Israel went into the midst of the sea on dry ground, with the waters a wall to them on their right hand and on their left.
verses.comment: Their passage through water prefigures New Testament realities—Baptism (see 1 Cor. 10:2) initiates believers into the life of grace, a spiritual crossing from death to life.

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued and followed them into the midst of the sea, all Pharaoh’s horses, his chariots, and his horsemen.
verses.comment: The Egyptians’ relentless pursuit represents the persistence of evil against God's people. Their destruction in water foreshadows the defeat of sin through Christ’s victory.

verses.text: During the morning watch, the LORD looked down on the Egyptian army from the pillar of fire and cloud and troubled the Egyptian army.
verses.comment: God’s supernatural presence intervenes at a decisive moment. Fire and cloud reappear later with a spiritual meaning: God’s Spirit at Pentecost.

verses.text: He caused the wheels of their chariots to come off so that they had trouble driving. So the Egyptians said, “Let’s flee from Israel, for the LORD is fighting for them against Egypt.”
verses.comment: God not only shields His people but actively destroys their oppressors. Recognition by the Egyptians of the LORD fighting for Israel anticipates Gentile recognition of the true God.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the sea so that the waters may come back upon the Egyptians, their chariots, and their horsemen.”
verses.comment: Moses’ act brings divine judgment through physical means. It again affirms the mystery of God working with—rather than independently of—human instruments.

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and at daybreak the sea returned to its normal flow while the Egyptians were fleeing into it. The LORD overthrew the Egyptians in the midst of the sea.
verses.comment: God’s judgment is total and final. This points to the reality of divine justice—sin is ultimately defeated, and God delivers His people.

verses.text: The waters returned and covered the chariots and horsemen, the whole army of Pharaoh that had followed them into the sea; not one of them remained.
verses.comment: None of Pharaoh's forces survived—God’s absolute sovereignty depicted here later echoes in New Testament images of spiritual warfare.

verses.text: But the Israelites walked on dry ground through the sea, with the waters a wall to them on their right and on their left.
verses.comment: Israel’s safe passage is the prototypical image of deliverance—from slavery to freedom. It is an Old Testament type fulfilled in Christ’s salvation.

verses.text: On that day the LORD saved Israel from the hand of the Egyptians. And Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the shore of the sea.
verses.comment: The visible evidence of victory reinforces the certainty of God’s deliverance—foreshadowing Christ’s resurrection as evidence of deliverance from death.

verses.text: When Israel saw the great power that the LORD used against the Egyptians, the people feared the LORD and believed in the LORD and in His servant Moses.
verses.comment: Faith is deepened through witnessing God’s mighty acts. This mirrors the apostolic and sacramental mode of faith—believing not in isolation, but as a community, with divinely appointed leadership.
